sections.title: Getting Git on Your System
sections.content: Before you can start using version control, you need to install Git on your computer. This lesson will guide you through the installation process for Windows, Mac, and Linux systems.

sections.title: Key Concepts
sections.content: Git installation varies by operating system, with different installation methods for Windows, Mac, and Linux. Initial configuration requires setting up your user identity so Git knows who is making changes. GitHub Desktop provides a graphical alternative for those who prefer a visual interface over command line tools. Command line Git offers more advanced features and is the standard for professional development. Proper setup ensures smooth collaboration and prevents authentication issues later.

sections.title: Installation Steps
content: Check if Git is already installed (git --version)
Download Git from the official website for your OS
Install with default settings for beginners
Install GitHub Desktop for GUI alternative

sections.title: Initial Git Configuration
sections.content: After installing Git, you need to configure your identity. Use these commands to set up your username and email:
sections.code: git config --global user.name "Your Name" git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com" git config --list

sections.title: Git Configuration Explained
sections.content: Git configuration is essential because it tells Git who you are when you make commits. The user.name and user.email settings are used to identify the author of each commit in the project history. The --global flag applies these settings to all your Git repositories on this computer. You can also set repository-specific configurations using the same commands without the --global flag. The git config --list command shows all your current Git settings, helping you verify that everything is configured correctly.
